I honestly wanted to play and love anthem. But it was just so grindy and shallow and the mechanics were unintuitive. It was a great looking game and flying around was awesome. But the grind was not good and the loot drops were awful. The weapons not being awesome and different was so bad. Not having legendary weapons that had special effects or some kind of special function was a major failure.
All they had to do was look at Destiny‚Ä¶. What do you think of when it comes to that game if you played it‚Ä¶.? Gjallarhorn, fatebringer, ace of spaces, whisper of the worm.
Like come on‚Ä¶ you had plenty of examples of looter shooters to pull from. 
But today we know why anthem failed‚Ä¶. Lack of direction and vision, and lack of a cohesive team.
I was just about to comment the same exact thing. My faith in bioware as a company is nonexistent. They really need to hit it out of the park with ME5 or they will be shut down.

Corporations continue to prop up studios they KNOW to be lacking, still holding the logo aloft like a gold standard - this is the phantom video game crash, that they take strides in occluding, camouflaged with bells and whistles.

The days of a human being getting in touch with the audience and taking responsibility for a lacklustre game......long gone.

Gaming has been 'corporatized'. So it's throw the Studio under the bus and stand there, unmoving, uncaring corporate like a wall of legal Kevlar that in no way holds anyone responsible for the shitty games farted out the door in too short a timeframe and on too little funds.

That's what we get for our loyalty and the pots and pots of gold they get to haul away so the investors can feast.

I think for the $10 I paid for this game it has some goodness. Do not come to this game looking for a good story/dialog or characters with Yarrow being the exception. Also be prepared as with Destiny to be forced to do certain lower power content with others versus a private mission. I do like that there is matchmaking available for the higher level content as I think I will need the help, unlike Destiny which has no matchmaking for the higher content that you need the help in. So far though as a level 25 without even switching classes, having fun with anthem and I feel like you can solo most of the hard content haven't unlocked grandmaster difficulty yet but looking forward to it.
I don't notice the load time to be nearly as much of a problem as it probably was at launch.

Destiny still has plenty of issues but I love the game for the massive growth it's story has gotten, and the consistently fun gameplay. And the LOOT!!!! Actual loot!

There are two major things that made me drop Anthem initially and those were the enemies and the story. 

The combat and exploration (while it certainly could be better) was fun and the game looked gorgeous at times.
Though I share AJ's concern and beef with it on pretty much all points.

The enemies are completely forgettable and don't feel like they differ from eachother much which is a huge problem when you spend so much time fighting them.
Mass Effect (the trilogy) worked so damn well because the enemies were interesting and felt distinct. 
Most importanly, they felt like they belonged in that world and had some motivation of their own with a fleshed out origin and history that developed throughout the game as you learned more about them and became more motivated to fight them.

As for the story, well... We all know what a crap sandwich that was. It simply isn't finished, it feels disjointed, makes little sense and... 
It's Destiny all over again; a solid base that was never developed properly. Just an exercise in wasted potential.

Saying what hasn‚Äôt been said yet ‚Äì and needs to be! 

My intention is not to foment discord or to be a rabble-rousing troublemaker. EA has done a great job of doing that all by themselves.  However, the very, very painful exercise of watching EA and BioWare attempt to launch Anthem brings to the surface some really angry feelings because I am one of the suckers who paid them in cash during a retail transaction for a purported AAA game that was ready to launch. 

Let me state that I have been involved in the software industry for decades, I‚Äôve held roles as developer. tester, project manager, implementation, administration, C level executive, and everything in between.  

I understand the business of software, and of game development. I understand why certain business decisions are made in software, so I come at this post with an abundance of knowledge. 

This game is nowhere near complete and it should never have been released at this point in time. Having said all that it is clear to me that EA is using the retail channel to support development of their game. Essentially, they are Crowdsourcing the funds to finish the game.  

One has to wonder why exactly the decision was made to release the game now. That decision by itself was flawed because it put Anthem on competitive grounds with Apex Legends.  From a business decision perspective you have to wonder if the executives at EA have a clue as to what they‚Äôre doing and why anyone would invest cash into EA seeing how disastrous the executive leadership of the company's decision making is.

Well it's hard to believe the executives at EA and BioWare to completely ignorant and to some extent probably do know what they‚Äôre doing ‚Äì which leaves the true option we should consider which is they wanted the cash and didn‚Äôt care that the game was unfinished. This is only logical conclusion that we can come up with‚Ä¶ after so many years in development the company was desperately seeking revenue to offset those costs. Unfortunately, the developers did not deliver for whatever reason and I don‚Äôt care what the reason is. Management at EA apparently wanted to recoup some money and really didn‚Äôt care how damaging their actions could be to themselves and the gaming industry as a whole.  Also, I don‚Äôt think they considered the liability position that they have put themselves in now (more on that later). 

Having experienced a month of patches with each successive Patch breaking more things, and doesn‚Äôt actually fix anything substantially, it‚Äôs becoming painfully obvious that the development team is either misguided or clearly doesn‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing. It‚Äôs entirely possible that executive leadership is directing them to do incredibly stupid things, or they just suck at writing code and testing it, or both.  

It‚Äôs really hard to say which one it is because it‚Äôs nearly unbelievable that the dev team actually tests this software or plays this game before releasing it given how in-your-face the bugs are.  This is about as botched as it gets and I never imagined the day where I would buy a game that was buggier and unfinished than The Division was, but Bioware was determined to show everyone just how screwed up of a game they could release. Meanwhile Massive and UbiSoft took their flaws seriously and fixed The Division, and launched a gem with The Division 2.

However there‚Äôs a problem that goes beyond just releasing a buggy game and I believe that EA crossed the line that protects consumers in the US, namely the Consumer Protection laws.  

I know there is a fine line here especially in software and I understand the delicate balance between fixing every bug and getting a product that is good enough out the door. Anthem goes nowhere near either one of those and is in such a bad state that consumers could complain that they didn‚Äôt receive what was advertised.   

Could you imagine how angry you would be if your computer or cell phone had as many flaws as Anthem does? or how about your car, or your refrigerator or your TV, or the clothes you buy, or just about anything else that you Purchase in a retail setting. Now that could be a fun game‚Ä¶coming up with ways different consumer products could be defective inspired by the Anthem debacle‚Ä¶such as you buy a new car and go to start it but instead the windows roll down and the horn sounds! 

Frankly I think that if people started demanding refunds from EA, Microsoft and Sony (copies sold via their stores) then EA would be forced to behave like a company that respects the public market they have the privilege of selling into.  If, or rather when, these company reject your refund request then I would say that people should file complaints with their state Attorney‚Äôs General. The point of the AG is to protect the consumer and EA is making a turkey shoot of the consumer market. If you don‚Äôt know who the AG is in your state, just query Google. 

If this were a piece of software targeting a business then I wouldn‚Äôt say any of this because you‚Äôre supposed to know what you‚Äôre doing in business. However, the target customer is the US retail consumer and certain protection laws apply. 

The behavior exhibited by EA and Bioware cannot be allowed to stand and sets a terrible precedence for the game and software industry as a whole. And this behavior should be punished to deter it from happening again.  They are the ones who made the decisions to release the game in the state that it is, instead of continuing to refine the code until they got it right or at least to the point where they could reasonably say they delivered what was advertises ‚Äì they are nowhere near that now.  

Meanwhile the company is asking everyone who shelled out their hard earned money to stick around and wait some indeterminate period of time, probably up to a year before the game is properly playable.  And I‚Äôm going to use a quote from the game itself to describe what is happening with the executive decisions in the game ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just wrong‚Äù. 

I firmly believe that business schools should use this as a case study on how not to create and release software. I also believe that EA unwittingly damaged the long-term revenue possibilities of this game by releasing it this way. What‚Äôs going to happen is the player base will abandon the game and quite possibly file lawsuits for consumer fraud.  

But even worse for EA, another competent studio and competent publisher will create a game with similar mechanics because it‚Äôs fun to fly around like Iron Man and Anthem publicly demonstrates this.  Too bad for EA and BioWare because there are a lot of good developers out there who can make a game with similar mechanics.  

I am not going to stick around while Bioware figures out how to write in test code before giving it to the public. Now, pay attention: if Massive and Ubisoft put jetpacks in the division 2 I believe half the player base of Anthem would immediately flock to that product.  

So I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs in Bioware and EA‚Äôs future but it could be class action lawsuits and administrative actions against them. I‚Äôm in favor of the litigation and looking for the first attorney to file the class action suit.  Enough nonsense from a company that enjoys all the benefits of the US consumer market while flaunting the rules that protect consumers from defective products.

¬†@eval_is_evil¬† I wasn't about to get into the specific details of the analysis you allude to regarding costs, schedules, etc., in this forum as it's not needed.  The most important part of the post is that EA knowingly released a game that was unfinished to the consumer market. Half of the value proposition of the game is missing- essentially cheating consumers of money based on the promise of a game that was purportedly complete but we all know it's no where near fit to be released. A lot of people are wandering why Bethesda or EA are releasing half baked products and just plain bad games. It's actually easy and obvious. It's all about investment and return. These companies are getting bigger and bigger and are probably run by corporate suits, which have no clues about videogames but have their head full of marketing notions. Fallout 76, considering the overall quality, didn't require a lot of money to produce (same engine, assets, bugs, etc) but from a marketing point of view was still successful because a lot of people bought it considering the success of the overall franchise. Was it a commercial success? Definitely not, but it probably made more money than how much it required to produce it. Anthem was a Minimum Viable Product, releasing a product with only basic features, kinda like a big "focus test group", and if the customers likes it, the company will improve on it. Too bad this system doesn't work for videogames. I think this is the only reasonable interpretation for the behavior of these companies. In the end, it's probably profitable, because they still get a higher return compared to the initial investment (ROI). Does this mean this is a good strategy? It is according to the corporate suits, but terrible for the overall quality of the products. Long story short, vote with your wallets, never preorder, buy the standard editions and wait for the reviews before purchasing. It's the only way to make this system not profitable anymore. I was miffed to see Baz and Stokes all smiles and shaking hands after the Wellington defeat in February, inexplicable after a defeat. It all felt too chummy - being unfazed after defeat is one, but being smiles all around ?! Oh, they do things to people with just a PLAYLIST. I had a playlist with a name "Fake News" and got a strike - I didn't upload the video; I just put it in a playlist. They ended up removing the video that was a critique of CNN. It's not that it wasn't a valid video - they took it down and I got a strike for having shared it. I think the problem is Google. I don't think it was this way when Yahoo owned it. When Google bought it, they also wanted people to use their REAL names. Yahoo had told us NOT TO because of the danger of using real names. I told them I would lose followers as I had this user name for years before. I was not going to start over again. Not sure what made them decide I could keep it. The argument that Yahoo had said not to use our real names? I dunno. Facebook is the same way. I've got some of my own content, but there are some videos I want to upload using fair use because it's going to be taken down due to political correctness eventually. Moving to other media platforms that promote free speech and fair use of banned videos. Hope you find a place to get your videos posted. Totally agree about the Google plus issue. That's part of the "real name" business. The only way I could use it was to use my handle as a business which it's not.

It says you CAN use their material for those reasons. (don't want to 
type so much). It does NOT say you won't have to deal with the system. 
Look, you use their stuff, they still have a right to fight with you 
about things. A huge misconception about fair use. But yes, you chose to
 be a content creator, you chose to be an entertainer using other 
people's work. Therefore, you too, suffer like Hollywood/gaming 
industries have to suffer too. You share in their suffering. South Park 
got sued over the "What What In The Butt" parody, won over fair use... 
but still, the copyright holder still had the right to sue and file a 
claim. Its just part of the game man. It says you have a right to use 
their stuff to make your videos, but it says NOTHING about 
THEM.............. NOT being able to give you a hard time about it. Grow
 up and just deal with it. Its the way of the business man. Its just the
 way it is.

Really, does it say anywhere they have no right to file claims against you? No it does not. So you use their stuff, fair use. Okay. But they also have a right to file a claim. Fair use. Its just the way of the business. Content creators on YouTube need to grow up and face the facts.

I played the game in 2025. I won't talk about bugs here ‚Äî just one oversight that negatively impacts the gameplay.

Reloading your weapon is mapped to the R key.

Looting all nearby enemies is also mapped to the R key.

During longer firefights (fortunately, there aren't too many ‚Äî ha!), you might move your cursor over a freshly fallen enemy and instinctively hit R to reload. But instead of reloading, the game opens the looting interface for nearby items dropped by enemies. That's not great.

Same old cycle of go here,kill,loot, do a quest by killing and no unique ways to solve quest,go to turn in quest or just finish quest after killing and repeat. Same as boring Fallout 4. Bethesda isn't good at hiding the basic game mechanics like Obsidian and Interplay were with their Fallout games. Fallout 3 was only saved by Bethesda playing it safe and copying Fallout 1 and 2 while being in 3d and not turn based. They watered down the mechanics and choices so much while making it a building game and a game that wants to be many things at once while not being great at what Fallout is known for, choice and consequences with multiple ways to solve quests or other mysteries like with New Vegas. F4 and F76 can be enjoyed for only so long before the loop just blatantly becomes obvious and becomes boring. It's dependent on the person for how long it will take and if they are a a new player to the franchise or not. Someone that's new to the games might really enjoy it but someone who has played since Fallout 1 or Fallout 3 will more than likely not enjoy it due to how those games have so many choices and hides the loop that every game has.

I have been playing 76 since launch on and off on Xbox and have about 300ish hours. I got the delux pre order that came with the helmet and I felt really betrayed by Bethesda. Fallout 4 is one of my favorite games of all time and so I was super exited when 76 was announced. The world just didn't feel like a fallout game before wastelanders. I've now had about 20 hours playing wastelanders also on Xbox, and I have completed the main plot and some of the ally quests. Once wastelanders came out it felt like a whole new product. Lots of the locations were the same but it just felt so much more filled out and lifelike. The alloys (companions) are a bit of a disappointment, most of their quests are just, go here get this, or go there kill that. Also, some really well written and well voice acted moments are ruined by the bad animations as the gravity of things is lost when the npc's are limited to so few movement patterns. My final critique would be that you cant explore more than one option in a situation. I get that Bethesda wants to make players have to choose and stick with their choice but still, one of my favorite aspects of previous fallout games was the ability to quicksave before an important conversation and see what options I could explore. Too many times in wastelanders I wanted to say one this to see what would happen but didn't as I was worried it would damage my faction reputation of rewards later on. As an extension of this I would like the ability to try and kill every npc at crater or foundation. I thought that it was great in previous fallout games that you could just raid a whole town like diamond city just to see if you could. Yet, in wastelanders I cant do that because that might end my ability to associate with that faction. The grind to gain that status is so long that I don't want to risk losing that. Plus there's no real reward for just going on a murder spree (admittingly there isn't in previous fallout games either) so the game just kinda forces you to play by Bethesda rules when previous fallout games felt so good because you could make your own rules in your own world and cater the experience for what you desire. Wastelanders was a step in the right direction for fallout 76 and I am very excited to see what Bethesda bring out next (hopefully a price reduction on fallout 1st along with more new content). By no means is this game now perfect, there are still bugs and it is very much still fallout 76, but it is more on par with just a bad dlc then a burning fire of "microtransactions, the game". My pre wastelanders rating of the game would be a 3/10 and post watelanders 7.5/10. Both of those are not compared to all other rpgs but as far as fallout games go 76 may yet grow into one of the best!

German can sound very crisp and harsh, which is sometimes perceived as angry, but this is only the case when the speaker gives orders or really is angry.
A German native speaker, when they are in a good mood, adds words to a sentence that have not a meaning of their own, but add melody and gentleness to the language and take the harshness out of it, although the sentence gets longer (e.g. schlechterdings, vielleicht, m√∂glicherweise, gl√ºcklicherweise, leider, zweifellos, sicherlich, kaum, bestimmt, hoffentlich,¬†vermutlich)
They are called "Modalw√∂rter" and are used instinctively.
Their correct use may be the greatest challenge in learning German.

Skyrim Dawnguard:
- Has a focus on vampires with humans (or human like entities) hunting them. 

-Introduces new locations that are both expansions on the open world and a new entire  realm to explore. 

- includes new Vampire enemy types. 

- Expands on the vampire condition the player can gain that includes a new skill tree and a new transformation 

- includes new weapons/powerups that are themed with the established lore with the vampire conflict. 

- Story is written well and allows you to play either side.

RedFall: 
- has a hoard of vampires in a seemingly empty town hunted down by a dude-with-gun 

- Story is borderline non existant. 

- vampire enemies are lacking in difficulty because of both the ai and design 

- labelled as a multiplayer game but struggles with multiple people in a server.

Have to say Skyrim, a game over a decade old  handled vampires better...

Redfall is proof that even fun glamorous jobs like "video game reviewer" involve occasional hours of shit-work.  Arkane Austin has released some of my favorite games over the years: Arx Fatalis, Dark Messiah, Dishonoured, Prey.  The studio fell apart when the founder left.  Microsoft is just trying to claw back some of their investment before shutting it down.  Looking Glass, Bioware, Interplay, Black Isle, all had similar fates.  Now Arkane, Obsidian, inXile, and even mighty Bethesda are hemorrhaging talent and launching terrible games in a death spiral.  Good job Microsoft.
Joe pulled out all the throwbacks

i hear the devs got super trolled making this but idk the full story. but yeah. it's safe to say devs do their best and care about what they make. i do understand it might be part of the "angry reviewer" persona to call devs lazy and stuff but i still disagree with it. would still work if it targeted the higher-ups of microsoft or arkane executives. it's not the devs who decide when the game should be released or even what the game will even be (sadly). as i understand it, especially in the AAA games industry, devs are basically just on payroll and model what they're told to model, program what they're told to program, etc. which btw is an inherent flaw to AAA projects in general, so many people are involved that on average the creative control each person has is very low. at the same time it's so expensive that big executives have to take a big interest in it, with a tendancy to play it safe and stick to a successfull formula. which ATM is open world action games. which clearly arkane staff weren't able to deliver under those conditions (mentioned in the "tl;dr")

it's hard to determine what was just executive decision making and how much was "this is the best we could achieve under those conditions within that time frame". according to what i've read it sounded like some devs wanted to salvage the work that's been done into a smaller scale single player game (towards the end of development, meaning they likely really wanted- and tried to make a good multiplayer game but began wanting something else once it became clear that wasn't feasible). 
i can imagine microsoft (or even arkane) executives forcing the game out tho despite this because they've promised to deliver a AAA multiplayer experience. knowing that if they put their employees in a grinder to have this dying, bleeding project sprint across the finish line and collapsing; to be stabilized by paramedics after the race is over, they could technically deliver. whereas changing course this late (though i suspect motivated by the fact it'd violate what was promised to microsoft let alone the public over anything else) could risk even more dev time and potentially a development hell that never ends. they'd rather get it over with and fail in a that's permissable than succeed in a way that is not.

tldr; as with most things it's often many simultaneous factors that contribute to the success and failure of a project. the acquisition of the company by microsft, the disorganization, distrurbance and staffing shortages that caused paired with an overpromised and unrealistic goal set by executives culminated in a game that was doomed to fail.

i suspect that even under those conditions, a shorter mission based game for 30 bucks could have been quite good and possibly have had some longevity through gamepass and updates. but microsoft wanted a big AAA open world blockbuster to advertise gamepass with, that may have even been a condition or motivation behind the acquisition. so...

This is so satisfying to watch since I didn't buy this garbage game lol ANYTIME Developers and promoters overuse the PAST success of a game studio as an advertising campeign, that should be an instant red flag. ALSO: If gamers used their brains more and tempered their excitement when new games release, perhaps somewhere BEFORE throwing money at undeserving studios, they would actually RESEARCH the game they intend to buy. There will ALWAYS be the gamers who lack common sense and buy the game, OR youtubers who lack imagination and let trends dictate their content, so let them make the dumb purchases, and then learn from them what games are actually worth the investment. A game studios past success does not automatically make them worthy of our money or time, so make them earn your respect with each new release, dont EVER take their word for it. Just a piece of advice that has saved me hundreds if not thousand of dollars.

That being said: I understand why Joe bought the game, as his channel is a game review channel, and in no way does my comment on lack of imagination apply to him or any of the other guys on his channel. I find this channel very entertaining, and appreciate the thought and effort put into each review. Its refreshing to see gamers who like myself still have a passion for gaming. Well done  Angry Joe!

The lack of mention about the father is likely due to Japanese culture and society rather than hatred of fathers or men. Fathers tend to have very little to do with their children in Japan (it's not necessarily their choice. A lot of it has to do with how many hours they are expected to work, and how after work they are expected to go out with colleagues or their boss, rather than go home to their families). Japanese men are at the bottom of the list compared to other countries when it comes to how much they contribute with child rearing and jobs in the home. It's not surprising that people from that background wouldn't consider including the father as important at all to include in this game (even more so given the character is female, as some believe men should have a bit more to do with their sons)
